security_audit.summary: All 19 static findings are false positives. The scanner incorrectly flagged common development terms (hash, content_hash, tree_hash) as cryptographic algorithms and the word C2 in a hash string as C2 malware terminology. The files contain only TDD methodology guidelines and JSON metadata - no executable code, network calls, file system access, or command execution. A previous security audit explicitly confirmed this is a benign instructional skill.

content.value_statement: Writing tests after code proves nothing about correctness. This skill enforces the RED-GREEN-REFACTOR cycle to ensure every feature has a failing test first. Write minimal tests, verify they fail, implement the simplest code to pass, then refactor with confidence.
actual_capabilities: Enforces RED-GREEN-REFACTOR cycle for all production code
Requires failing test before any implementation
Validates test failures match expected behavior
Detects architectural problems when tests repeatedly fail
limitations: Does not execute tests automatically - relies on user test runner
Does not write actual test code - provides methodology only
Cannot fix test infrastructure or environment issues
Applies only when user invokes the skill for coding tasks

use_cases.title: New feature implementation
use_cases.description: Add features with verified behavior through failing tests first

use_cases.title: Regression prevention
use_cases.description: Write failing tests that reproduce bugs before fixing them

use_cases.title: Quality enforcement
use_cases.description: Verify submitted code follows test-first methodology

prompt_templates.title: Add new feature with TDD
prompt_templates.scenario: Need to implement a new feature
prompt_templates.prompt: Use test-driven-development to add a feature that describes desired behavior. Write a failing test first, then implement simplest code to pass it.

prompt_templates.title: Fix bug with TDD
prompt_templates.scenario: Need to fix a reported bug
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply test-driven-development to fix the bug. Start by writing a test that reproduces incorrect behavior, then fix the code.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor safely
prompt_templates.prompt: Use test-driven-development to refactor the code section. Write tests that verify current behavior, then refactor with confidence.

prompt_templates.title: Greenfield project
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up test-driven-development workflow for this new project. Define the RED-GREEN-REFACTOR cycle and apply it to the first feature.

output_examples.input: Add user authentication with test-driven-development skill
output: RED: Writing first failing test for user login...
Test fails as expected - function not implemented
GREEN: Implementing minimal auth code to pass test...
REFACTOR: Cleaning up while tests remain green...
Code is ready for next behavior

output_examples.input: Fix the sorting bug using test-driven-development
output: RED: Writing test that reproduces the sorting issue...
Test correctly fails showing incorrect sort order
GREEN: Implementing minimal fix to pass the test...
REFACTOR: Improving sort implementation while tests green...

best_practices: Always write one failing test that demonstrates exactly one behavior
Run tests to verify they fail before writing implementation code
Implement the simplest code possible to pass the test first
Only refactor when all tests are green
anti_patterns: Writing code before tests - delete all untested code
Rationalizing skipping tests for simple changes
Adding features not requested by the failing test
Leaving tests that pass immediately - they prove nothing

faq.question: Which test frameworks work with this skill?
faq.answer: This is a methodology skill that works with any testing framework like Jest, Pytest, JUnit, Vitest, or Go testing.

faq.question: How many tests should I write at once?
faq.answer: Write one failing test at a time. Focus on a single behavior per test to maintain clarity.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with my existing codebase?
faq.answer: Invoke the skill when starting any new feature or bug fix. It does not modify your test infrastructure.

faq.question: Is my test code stored or shared?
faq.answer: No. This skill only provides methodology guidance. Test code remains local to your project.

faq.question: What if my tests fail unexpectedly?
faq.answer: The skill includes guidance for when three or more fixes fail - signals architectural problems requiring discussion.

faq.question: How is this different from writing tests after?
faq.answer: Tests written before code catch edge cases early, document expected behavior, and prove the implementation works.
